title: On the Promise of Topic Models for Abstracting Complex Medical Data: A Study of Patients and their Medications

author: Jenna Wiens, Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT

segmentation: Good afternoon, my name is Jenna Wiens and I'll be presenting work done in collaboration with my advisor John Gatech and Eric Horvitz.

So as many of you probably already know, the goal of topic modeling is to find a set of latent variables that explain complexities and observed data and topic models have been applied successfully in many different areas, often to collections of text documents.
So here we have an illustrative example where a set of topics is learned from a collection of NIPS papers, and then this allows one to describe each paper as it set of most probable topics.
So what does this have to do with personalized medicine?

Well, we're intrigued by this form of automatic abstraction, and we have prophesized that topic models can be used to discover useful abstractions about hospitalised patients in an unsupervised manner.

So first, given a large database of patient records, we treated each patient visit as a document and the administered medications as words, and we trained a topic model.

So interpretation for this topic is heart failure because all of these medications may be given to a patient with heart failure.
